Name: Days of Iron: Rules for Wargaming the Franco-Prussian War
Description:
These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Franco Prussian War period.

Days of Iron is a set of rules for 15mm wargaming at the regimental scale.  Cavalry and Infantry stands represent 50 men each.  Artillery, Engineers, and Staff stands represent 10 men each.  An artillery gun model represents three actual guns.

Name: Spokaneopoly
Description:
Spokaneopoly is a clone of Monopoly set in the city of Spokane Washington. The game board locations are businesses and attractions from the city.

From the publisher: Welcome to a Spokaneopoly, the game of financial domination, As a player, you will become a major part of the entrepreneurial system of our fiscal community, buying, selling and trading well-known businesses and local landmarks. Spokaneopoly emphasizes the allegiance and true spirit that make this community so wonderful. Included in this game are some of the finest and most celebrated businesses, attractions and sites throughout the area.

Name: Cannonball Charlie
Description:
Players spin to see what type of plastic brick to add to the wall being built in front of Charlie, who patiently bides his time in the shaft of an elastic-band loaded cannon.  When a certain weight threshold is exceeded, the elastic band trigger is released, propelling Charlie into the wall and eliminating the player who caused this to occur from the game.

The remaining players reset the cannon, replace Charlie & rebuild the wall from scratch, again trying to prevent Charlie from crashing into and collapsing the wall.

The last player remaining is the winner.

Name: Subdoku
Description:
Subdoku takes the battleship game into a new dimension!
Nine pawns in three different colors. You can't place pawns of the same color in the same square, row or column.
With those Sudoku rules the battle become smarter and much more strategic then ever before. The battle of mind starts here…

Name: Horton Hears a Who! You to the Rescue!
Description:
Horton Hears a Who! - You to the Rescue!
The jump-up-and-go silly search game!

Go on a wild adventure to save the Whos! Put on the Horton hat and race around the house to find the clovers where the tiny Whos live. Pick them up with your trunk—then hurry back before time runs out! The player who rescues the most Whos is the winner!

Horton Hears a Who! – You to the Rescue! brings the classic Dr. Seuss book to life, giving kids a whole new incredibly fun way to experience this favorite Dr. Seuss story.

Name: The Grinch: Sing Your Heart Out!
Description:
The game of team-work, singing and surprising sleigh-rides!

The Grinch is out to steal the Whos’ gifts—but your family can save the day. Only your singing will warm the Grinch’s heart and bring his sleigh full of stolen gifts speeding down Mt. Crumpit and back to Who-ville!

Collect Who tiles and gifts with each player’s turn. But watch out—draw the wrong tile and the Grinch will steal the gifts back! When that happens, team up with your family or friends: If you sing LONG ENOUGH and LOUD ENOUGH, the Electronic Singing Detector will hear your singing and actually launch the sleigh on its wild ride down Mt. Crumpit! Connect all 12 Who Tiles plus matching gifts, and you win!

Name: Star Sight
Description:
Star Sight is a space exploration and conquest game played on an enormous hexagonal array of triangles.  Players gain points for building ships, creating space colonies, destroying opponents' units, and delivering cargo.  The player with the most points after a predetermined number of turns is the winner.

Players command their fleet by simultaneously entering commands for their ships into logbooks, which are then revealed and adjudicated.

Name: Black Sheep
Description:
All the sheep ran away to the meadow; the players compete with each other to bring back the most sheep to the pen and try to stop the other players from doing the same.
In this fast card game each player tries to get rid of all his cards and especially of the black-sheep card. If that doesn't work, 3 black sheep can win the game!

Currently published only in Hebrew, in Israel.

Name: Spell a Spell
Description:
This game will determine who the most powerful wizard is. You cast your spell using magic letters, spell words, and spell cards.
Creativity, quick thinking and imagination create a challenging game for the whole family.
The winner is the wizard that left untouched while all the other wizards are turned into bewitched wizards.

Name: Flips & Flops
Description: Use your wits, guts and drop of luck on your way to the gold, in this exciting memory game. You will advance along the track by flipping the jumping cards. jumping over an opponent will send him back. Try to avoid the crocodile cards and be the first to reach the end of the track, pick the gold medal and win the game.

Name: World Cup Cricket
Description:
Players represent the batting and fielding sides in a game of limited overs cricket.
The fielding player sets up his field using white counters to depict his fielders. Counters also represent the batsman and umpires, though these are static.
For each ball in an over, a card is drawn from the deck to represent the outcome of that bowl (no ball, howzat etc.), and the result is recorded in an authentically detailed score book - meaning that at the end of the innings the scores will be represented as in a real match. The positioning of the field affects the likelihood of the batsmen being given out as well as the number of runs they will score.
The box includes: Game board, with all the major fielding positions marked; counters to represent fielders, batsmen and umpires (including several spares); a deck of cards for drawing each ball of the over; An in/out die (green and red sides); A fully authentic cricket score book; four blank cards for replacement/original outcomes.

Name: InQuest Board Game
Description:
From the publisher: 
InQuest Board Game is an exciting interactive, competitive and challenging game of fun, crime, mystery, forensics and law. For 2 to 8 players. You can win by answering questions in six informative categories at three levels of complexity. “No crimes to solve and no clues to track.” Show off your social and observational skills by answering questions yourself, or ask someone for help… but will they tell you the truth? Are they really your friends?

Name: Master of Television
Description:
From the publisher homepage:

MASTER OF TELEVISION
This is the perfect board game about the box! So turn off the telly and turn on the fun in this fast-paced game, where your knowledge of the biggest and the best series of Television are at stake. Stop fighting about the remote control – Fight to become the Master of Television.

Background
THE ULTIMATE TRIVIA GAME FOR EVERYONE WHO LOVES TELEVISION.
In MASTER OF TELEVISION it’s all about how well you know the famous series of the television – You have to know a little about a lot – From "Friends" to "Big Brother". From "McCloud" to "The Eurovision Song Contest", everything can show up on your "screen".
You play to become MASTER OF TELEVISION. The 8 categories cover Drama, Comedy, Shows, even gossip, scandals, strange TV-facts and much much more.
At the very end it comes down to a memorable Quote from a famous TV Series – Who said it and in what series.
MASTER OF TELEVISION is fun, exiting, entertaining and you can never predict how it ends.
MASTER OF TELEVISION can be played by everyone – age is no limitation.

Gameplay
Just like any good night in front of the television MASTER OF TELEVISION entertains from the moment you open the box. You’re ready to play right away, without complicated rules or introductions. You simply play your way through 7 of the 8 categories and when you’ve gathered 7 "Flat Screens", you’re going to face the final question – Recognizing a quote from a TV series and you have to tell your fellow players which TV Quote originated from what TV Series. Then you’ve earned the title MASTER OF TELEVISION.
MASTER OF TELEVISION guarantee you the best TV night without TV.

MASTER OF TELEVISION is the second game in a series of games with the title "Master of….". Next games will be "Master of Music" and "Master of Sports" – More to come…

Name: Command Horizon
Description:
Set in the 26th Century, the Command Horizon universe offers the chance to collect armies from the various powers, factions, companies, mercenaries and pirates that all compete for power and resources in Human Space.

Thus far, Man has found himself alone in his corner of the Galaxy, but it is only a matter of time before he meets other races whose technological development may equal or even surpass his own.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Dick Tracy: A "Sunday Funnies" Game
Description:
From the box lid:

Track down arch criminals with America's #1 detective.

Meet up with some of the most famous villains in comic strip history.  FLATTOP... MOLE... MUMBLES... PRUNEFACE... VITAMIN FLINTHEART... THE BROW... SHAKEY... LITTLEFACE.  Go after them all.

Start from HQ and track 'em down one by one...go in and out of hiding places...pick up cards trying to get 4 that match.  There may be some dangers along the way, so watch out.  The first player to get 4 matching Criminal Cards and enter that criminal's hideout with those cards wins the game.

Name: Monte Carlo
Description: Thirty-six tiles numbered one through nine of four colors are dealt to the players. Each player has twelve chips to use to make bids based on which the players will play combination of tiles. As combinations are made, the players receive their rewards. The first player to score a predetermined number of chips is the winner.

Name: Pondusspillet
Description:
Pondusspillet is a game based on the Norwegian comic strip with the same name, made by Frode Øverli.

The game is a trivia game with a wide range of questions, but mainly from English football, Pondus' main interest. Although the questions can be very hard, they are made easier by leaving the player only two alternatives.

It is also possible to "tackle" a player by answering questions on his or her behalf.

Contents:
- Game board
- 4 playing pieces
- 2 dice
- 240 trivia cards

Name: Holy Hack: Biblical Warfare 3000 B.C. to 600 B.C. -Hacking by the Book (Second Edition)
Description:
From the rulebook: "Revised and expanded to include warfare in The Near East, Egypt and Africa in Old Testament Times.   Includes general orders of battle, tactics, formations, revised casualty calculation method, diagrams, naval & siege rules, Divine Intervention, heroic challenges & Q.R.S.

"Originally published as `Holy Hack: Hacking By the Book Biblical Warfare.'"

This rulebook also features enhanced graphics throughout including color illustrations of examples using photographs of miniatures in play.

For support online, see http://www.classicalhack.com
Families: History: Wars in the Ancient Near East

Name: Inside the Armor
Description:
A game about damage control inside Fletcher class destroyers in WWII.  This Playtest Kit has one scenario: the USS Johnston at the Battle off Samar.  It's solitaire.

https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1qZcMaMDIG_GBYIfiv7LWEBPBUHCvFmw5?usp=drive_link

All feedback welcome.

Cheers,
Jonathan Tristram Miller

Name: Avista Pro
Description:
Avista Pro is a sister game to Avista. Players try to find out a word matching the conditions on cards. First card gives a subject and second card gives initial letter for the word.

Avista Pro uses more difficult subjects than Avista. They are further divided into three difficulty levels: easy, moderate, and difficult.

Avista Pro is really just the 2nd edition of Avista, rather than a self-standing game; the rules are exactly the same, the number of cards is exactly the same, and the first edition already had three difficulty levels; whether the subject matters are more difficult or not is arguable.

Name: The Backyardigans Game
Description:
(From Game Box)

Make imaginative play and important part of each day. The Backyardigans Game lets kids sail on a Pirate Adventure or blast off on a Mission to Mars with their favorite pretend friends, Pablo, Uniqua, Tyrone, Tasha and Austin!

As they play kids will practice:

Color Matching
Picture Matching
Taking Turns

Name: Heroic Frenzy: Petrograd 1919
Description:
In July 1919, General Yudenich was made Commander-in-chief of the Northwestern army of the Whites, and was recognized by Kolchak as his representative. In August, with the aid of England and Esthonia, the Russian “Northwestern Government” was established. Yudenich’s planned Fall offensive was timed to coincide with the pinnacle of the White’s success, as Denikin approached Orel and Tula, the munitions-manufacturing center. From there it was only a short distance to Moscow. Heroic Frenzy covers the battle for Petrograd during this time.

The map scale is about 3-3.5 miles per hex. Each aircraft unit represents one aircraft, each tank unit equals one AFV (armored fighting vehicles), and each armor car unit represents three armor cars. White units are brigades (X), battalions (II). Red units are brigades (X). A game turn represents two days.

Name: Crossword
Description: Koplow's Crossword game consists of seven dice showing a variety of letters or blanks (wild letters) in two colors.  On his turn a player rolls all seven dice, then makes words with the letters, crossword style, within an agreed upon time limit.  Scoring is one point per letter used, however any complete word made using only one letter color scores two points per letter.

Name: Euro-game
Description: The goal of of the game is to let people get acquainted with the new European currency, the Euro. The game is a roll-and-move game with questions and answers and chance, option and assignment cards. You win by getting a complete series of Euro-coins and notes.

Name: Einfach Genial Junior
Description:
From the rules (translated):

Professor Eisstein has invented the best penguin-food ever.  Unfortunately, the absent-minded Professor has accidentally lost his new food pellets on ice floes in the sea. Can you help the Professor find all the food pellets and feed the penguins?

As the name implies, this is a simplified, kiddy-friendly version of Knizia's classic Ingenious. Whilst the tile placement rules are largely unchanged, players score by collecting penguin food chits and "feeding" them to their penguins.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Boy Scout Game
Description:
This roll-and-move game is set in a Boy Scout camp and the surrounding farmground.  One imagines it was either published in the first half of 1914, before WWI broke out, or had very limited sales. 
Each player starts on his/her own (coloured)route; ending on a marked space follow instructions; first player entering the centre (camp of tents) is the winner.

Name: With Rucksack and Guitar
Description:
This roll-and-move game features hikers, who carry their guitar, flute, and rucksack, walking past the lakes, through the fields, and over the hills of Germany.  The pawns match the art on the box, complete with lederhosen.

The date of publication is pinned at "around 1925" in the Spears history, Games We Play.

Name: Car Racing
Description:
A racing game were each player has to playing pieces. One is the mechanic that you move around building your car and finding replacement parts as the game goes on. There are many various parts so each player gets his own custom made car, with different abilities ad weaknesses.

The other piece is a sand timer, that is used to represent your car on the race track. On a players turn, he choses whether he wants to move his mechanic or car, but when then sand has run out in the sand timer, the car is out of gas and you need to move the mechanic to refill the car.

The race track has various hazards and shortcut, that may or may not interfere with your car, depending on what custom parts your car is made up of. You might want to move the mechanic around to find you better car parts, but in the end it is the player who first reaches the finish line with his car who wins.

Name: Hvis du nu var...
Description:
A party game where the players are to guess what one of the other players would be if he was a specific object. For instance, one of the cards could read "If player X was a bike, what kind of bike would he be? A mountain bike, a racing bike, a three wheeler or a tandem?"
The other players will now simultaneously play a card stating what they think, and points will be awarded only to the players who think alike the majority.

Awards

2007 Ã…rets Familiespil, Family Game of the Year Denmark

Name: Flames of War: Villers-Bocage
Description:
Villers-Bocage is a source book for Flames of War covering the battles over this French crossroads town from 12-16 June 1944.

It includes army lists for the forces that fought the battles, including the 101 Schwere SS-Panzerabteilung (Tiger Battalion), The Panzer Lehr division and the British 7th Armored Division.  It also includes three historical scenarios that can be played individually or linked into a mini-campaign.  The scenarios include historical orders of battle, but also include suggestions for running them with alternate forces.

Basic painting guides and historical background are included as well.

Name: Ab auf die Insel
Description:
Get onto the island:

Finally, the sun is shining nice and brightly and the swimming pool in the garden is inviting you to enjoy some splashing around. As today was really strenuous, you'd prefer to lie down on your inflatable super cool palm island in the swimming pool, together with your two friends, and just float around. Unfortunately, your other family members have the same idea. But since there's only one air mattress, the turmoil starts right at the edge of the pool. Everyone wants to get to the air mattress first, since he who comes last goes empty handed.

Contents:

1 Game board

1 Die

12 game pieces

Name: Lost in Space
Description:
Creatures from another planet are lost in space. We have to take them home, using observation and grid references. An excellent introduction to using maps.

(From inside the box)

Lost in Space: A map reference game for any number of players

The six collecting boards form the plan of Fantasia. Each board is divided into nine grid squares, so that there are 54 grid squares in all. Each of the 54 picture cards shows, larger and more clearly, a creature from one of the grid squares, and on the back of the card the appropriate grid reference is shown. 
The aim of the game is to match the creatures to the grid squares, either through observation or by using the grid references.

The attractive design of this game belies the degree of observational skill required. It reflects the difficulty of reading real maps and quickly teaches the value and simplicity of grid references.

Name: Flower-garden
Description:
Four young gardeners have a communal garden in which each sets out to plant a row of flowers  However, that can be a complicated undertaking; sometimes the bed a gardener chooses is already planted or is reserved for a different color of flower.

Each player chooses a color peg and takes 8 flowers, two of each color.  The players take turns rolling the die and moving their pegs in any direction he chooses but only in one direction.  If a player lands on an un-planted flower bed and has a flower of the same color as the bed, he can plant his flower.  But if the bed is already planted or the player does not have a flower to match the bed, he may not plant a flower.  After a player moves, his turn is over.

The winner is the first play to plant all his flowers.

Name: Hund och Katt
Description:
Swedish game for children.

The dogs take on the cats in the back alleys. One player takes control of the dogs (six of them), the other the cats (equal amount). The players then take turns rolling the dice, moving their animals across the board. If your animal finishes its move on top of one of the opponent's you have won that fight and the loser is removed from play.

Whoever gets his animals knocked out first loses.

Name: Suomalainen Yleisurheilutietopeli
Description: A unique game full of sports trivia. Produced in cooperation with the national federation Finnish Athletics. The game contains hundreds of questions regarding Finnish sports heroes and events since the beginning of the Finnish independence in 1917. Includes also fabulous picture cards, in which the players try to recognise athletes and glorious moments from the history and present-day of Finnish sports.  Do you know... How tall is a hurdle in men’s 110 m hurdles? And how many Olympic bronze medals did Paavo Nurmi achieve? Find out all this and much more in the awesome Sports Trivia game!

Name: Way to the White House
Description:
Two to four players compete for Electoral votes, based on their knowledge of U.S. state capitols and their luck with a spinner. Starting with the player who has the spinner, the player who correctly guesses the state associated with a given capitol city gets to mark the state with his peg. When all states are claimed, the player with the most Electoral votes (as determined by the 1927 map board) is the winner.

At the time of this game, red was the color of the Democratic party and blue was that of the Republicans (vs. the current Republican=red state, Democrat=blue state association). For the third and fourth players, the Independent (yellow) and the Prohibition (natural) parties are also included.

This game was later sold, with minor cosmetic modifications, as E. E. Fairchild Corp.'s Battle of Ballots. The only major difference is that this version uses a spinner to randomly select capital cities, while the later version uses a deck of cards.

Name: Hopla Verstoppertje Spelen
Description:
Hopla Verstoppertje Spelen is a game for children from as old as 6 months to 4 years. For the youngest it's a game of finding Hopla (the well-known bunny) and for the older kids you can use the cards to give clues as to where Hopla might be hiding.

Hopla calls out 5 times (Hopla! Hopla! Hopla!) and needs to be found within that time. Different variants are in the game's rulebook and will be added to the website later on.

Name: The Animal Kingdom
Description:
Similar to Jungle, the forerunner of Stratego.

Each player has 13 animals, with strengths ranging from 1 to 13. The players move their animals orthogonally one space per turn and compare strengths between animals when one moves into an occupied space. The higher strength wins and captures the other animal, except in the case of the mouse (strength 1) which can capture an elephant (strength 13).

There is a set of variant cards with the game which will offer some variety to the game by granting powers.

Name: Spytak
Description: An espionage-themed game that included a Traka, an electronic number generator and game device.

Name: Krux
Description:
The goal of the game is to push or pull an opponent's piece so that it lands in the central hole.

Players do not choose which pieces to move, they play in a fixed order. However, rings can be placed on the pieces to give them special move alternatives like jumping and picking up other pieces.

Name: Middle East Smackdown
Description:
Middle East Smackdown is a 2-4 strategy board game set in the middle east. Players take control of the USA, Israel, Syria, Iran, Iraq and Lebanon for the final conflict in the middle east. Terrorism sponsored by Iran and Syria have pushed the US too far and now it is full scale war. The US and its allies are now out to conquer Iran and Syria completely. They have overwhelming technological superiority and the best trained troops in the world.

But Iran has some good defensive ground, lots of men for canon fodder, militant groups, terrorist insurgents and its most potent asset of all, the liberal politicians within the US house and senate. Can Iran manipulate the media and its liberal allies to get Congress to cut funding from the US military in order to stave off conquest and win the war? Can the US military complete the war with the forces it has in the fields if funding does get cut?

Middle East Combat Comes with:

1) 3 piece 16.5" x 31.5" full color game map.
2) 432 cut-out full color game counters on chipboard.
3) Game Rules
4) 1 Six Sided Die.
5) Resource Chart

Name: A Bug's Life Topple Hopper 3-D Game
Description:
Race your ants along a path while avoiding grasshoppers, Molt and Thumper.  Use grasshoppers to block your opponents.
Be the first to reach the end and topple Hopper.

Name: Winnie the Pooh Tip 'n' Topple Game
Description: Help Pooh and his friends climb the wobbly tree, but be careful. . . If the tree tips Pooh and Friends will t-t-topple! Be first to help all of your characters onto the tree to win.

Name: Tricky Topple
Description: It appears to be a roll and move game with other features.

Name: AA Game of the Road
Description:
An Exciting Car Touring Game.

Start at London, tour Great Britain and be the first to return. But be careful - the road is full of hazards laid by other players! Take the fast route and meet the hazards head on, or take the slow route and collect protection cards. Which is the best route to win the game?

Object

The aim is to go around the circuit and be the first to return to London.  The first player to do this is the winner.  Instead of a turn, you can lay hazards for other players.  When taking the longer route, you can stop at AA Service Centres and collect protection cards or take the shorter route and pass the other drivers.  If you land on another player's hazard counter he hands you a hazard card.  Do you have the right protection card? If not, call the AA van. When it arrives you can travel again.

Game Contents:

     Game Board
     5 Cars
     4 AA Vans
     5 Triangle Warning Signs
     20 Hazard Counters
     25 Hazard Cards
     20 Protection Cards
     1 Die
     Rules

Name: Śląsk 1939
Description: Slask 1939 (Silesia 1939) depicts the battle taking part in southwestern Poland during the 1939 invasion.

Name: Bolsão de Craques
Description: In this game, the players are acting as soccer managers, trying to complete your team in the best way, and  also trying not lose points because another soccer team's actions.

Name: Grab-A-Tiger
Description: This is a game where you have a spinner that tells you the color of the tiger's tail you have to grab.  You grab it with something almost identical to a plastic clothes pin.  The game is played in 3 rounds with the person catching the most tigers winning each round and 2 out of 3 rounds being the win.

Name: SQR
Description:
SQR Base is a turn-based strategy game for one or two players.

The game is played on a board made of square cells (though the board itself needn't be square). Each player will make a team of characters, the SQRs, to face an opponent. The object of the game can be either moving one or several neutral characters to a special cell, the Base (different for each player), defeating all the opponent's SQRs or conquering the opponent's Base.

Name: Mickey Mouse Don't Wake the Dragon Game
Description:
Each player takes turns to win charm cards & the player with the strongest charm wins the challenge, moves ahead one space or moves his opponent back one space.

The winner is the first player to save Minnie from the dragon.

Great nostalgic family fun !

Contents

1 x playing sheet 
15 x Magic charm cards

4 x Playing pieces

1 x Spinner

Name: Order of the Stick Adventure Game: The Linear Guild
Description:
Get your evil twin on! This is the upcoming expansion to the Order of the Stick Adventure Game: The Dungeon of Dorukan, featuring fully playable versions of villainous Nale, Sabine, Thog, and the rest.

This will be a stand-alone expansion to the The Dungeon of Dorukan and will not require the base game to play.  The expansion can be combined with the base game for even more gameplay options!

Rich Burlew basically announced that he had an illness that limited his health to the point that he had to devote all of his time to the comic (and the collection of said comics into books.) As he does the art for the game (and created the Order of the Stick world) and didn't have the time to devote to it, this expansion was put in limbo.

Name: Think a Dot
Description: In turn, a player drops a marble in any one of the three holes at the top of the device. The device contains eight flip-flops; three on the top row, two on the middle row and three on the bottom row. A flip-flop will change a window’s color from one to the other every time a marble hits it. The marble will exit the device from the left or the right. A player may continue taking a turn as long as the marble exits the device from the side chosen by that player. The object of this puzzle-game is to get a pre-determined sequence of colors to be revealed in the eight windows.

Name: The Game of Secession, or Sketches of the Rebellion
Description: The Game of Secession was produced to support the Union cause. The gameboard featured a line of numbers from 1 to 135 and pictures of people and events from the Civil War. The game was found in the Civil War Scrapbook of Andrew Dickson White, the first President of Cornell University.

Name: Risk 2210 A.D.: Terror Tactics Command Deck
Description:
With the race for supremacy becoming ever more desperate in a world driven by the war machine: with extremist views becoming the mainstay and with the political system being domineered by tyrannical warmongers, the time has come for...TERROR TACTICS!

No longer do bureaucrats endlessly try in vain to foster peace treaties between opposing factions. Instead they too have picked up their arms and having lost heart, fight for the ultimate stake – their own survival.

Where will this struggle end? Who will become the dominant power? The world's fate is in your hands!

DESCRIPTION

Terror Tactics is a 20 card second generation expansion to the Risk 2210 AD universe designed for use either in place of one of the five original command decks or through the introduction of an additional command token.

Expands:


     Risk 2210 A.D.

Name: Quick! Put the kettle on
Description:
This is a Snakes & Ladders-like game designed by cartoonist Simone Lia, themed around some of the recurring characters from her comic strips.

From the instructions:
"Each player chooses a character.  There are six to choose from: Chip, Bean, Worm, Robot, Snail and Sad Cloud.

The aim of the game is to be the first player to get to square 40 to 'Put the kettle on'."

Name: Moon Melee
Description:
In the not too distant future war and fighting have been banned on the planet earth.
All disputes are now resolved on the moon through hand to hand combat. Each nation involved in a dispute chooses its 7 most powerful warriors to compete in a decisive battle.

Moon Melee is an abstract strategy game in which players play cards to determine the movement of their warriors. The warriors are represented by dice and have a life force of 6.
Players take turns moving and attacking their opponents. When a warrior is reduced to a 0 life force they are removed from the game. The game takes place on a 7 X 7 square grid. The player with the most life force after 3 rounds is declared the winner.

Name: Mad Marbles
Description:
Game comes in a 14 1/2" x 14 1/2" x 2 1/2" box.

The orange plastic gameboard (similar dimensions to the box) resembles a square with rounded corners & concave sides. Each corner has a plastic 'gate' which is used to trap marbles & score points.

Each turn, marbles are introduced one at a time into a rotating transparent plastic chamber which occupies the center of the gameboard. As they roll wildly and with great speed around the board players attempt to trap them with their plastic gate. Although it is possible to squeeze more marbles behind the gate, there are only enough small depressions to safely hold three at any one time. There are eight marbles per turn - seven white (worth 1 point) and a single red marble worth 6 points which is always introduced into the rotating chamber last. At the end of each turn scores are tallied and the next player spins the central chamber.

The first player to reach 12 points wins.

Name: ABC: In the Jungle
Description:
From the publishers homepage:

ABC – In The jungle is the ultimate connection between playing and learning and is therefore a must for all children in their preparation for school.

While playing "ABC – In The jungle" children get familiar with the letters in a fun and inspiring way. "ABC – In The jungle" can be played in 2 different ways, so children can play with family and friends over and over in various ways.

Furthermore you can adjust the length of each Game to whatever time frame you want: The number of cards you choose to use in each Game determines the playing time of each round of fun learning.

Gameplay
The order of which a card matches a square on the Game Board is determined by the starting letter of the words from the picture on the card or the other way around if the card is a letter. For example, the card with the letter Z matches the picture of a Zebra on a square on the board. The card with a picture of an Owl, matches the square on the board with the letter O.

2-GAMES-IN-1:

GET RID OF THE CARDS
Each payer is dealt a number of cards (for instance 4 cards each). In order to get rid of a card, a player must land on the matching square. The first player to get rid of all his / hers cards have won.

COLLECT THE MOST CARDS
4 cards are laid face up and now they players have to collect as many as possible by going to the square they match. When a player collects a card, a new card is turned face up. Before the game starts, the Players agree on the number of cards in total (for instance 12 cards). When all cards are collected, the player with the most cards has won the game.

Name: Carriers: Battle of Midway
Description:
The year is 1942 and the Japanese navy is on the offensive.  With American naval units heavily depleted after Pearl Harbor and the Battle of Coral Sea, the Imperial Japanese Navy is seeking to strike a decisive blow and consolidate their hold on the Pacific, a prelude to further expansion for the Empire of Japan.

“Battle of Midway” is a turn based game of fleet strategy and close Carrier tactics, pitting the naval fleets of the United States Navy Pacific Fleet and the Imperial Japanese Navy against one another.

Based loosely on the actual events of the 4-7th June 1942 Battle of Midway, players take the role of either;

i) Supreme Commander Pacific Fleet of the US Navy in command of three Carrier Groups & one Battleship Group

or

ii) Combined Fleet Commander of the Imperial Japanese Navy in command of three Carrier Groups & one Battleship Group

The following Carriers & Battleships form the core of the Carrier Groups in this game;

United States Navy Pacific Fleet
1.) USS Enterprise
2.) USS Hornet
3.) USS Yorktown
4.) USS South Dakota

Imperial Japanese Navy
1.) IJN Akagi
2.) IJN Kaga
3.) IJN Hiryu
4.) IJN Yamato

Play is done on individual war charts which only show friendly fleet deployments with ship movements, attack phases and search phases plotted in real time. You have already been informed by Naval intelligence that the enemy fleet is no longer in port.  Where is the enemy fleet?  How are his ships arrayed?  What is their target objective?  Should you seek the enemy fleet before he strikes?  Should you push ahead with plans to land marines and take the strategic Pacific islands?  Or should you take the war to the enemy and attempt to sneak in a lightning strike on his now undefended home ports?

These are questions you need to answer as your battlegroup streams out to engage the enemy.  Visibility is only limited to the immediate area around your bases and ships.  You will need to send out spotter planes or submarines to screen your fleet as you race to the be first to find and engage the enemy before he finds you.  Enemy fleets must be found and destroyed, and the Commander with the best intelligence and planning will prevail!


                                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                        
                                                                                                                    
                                                                                                                
                                                                                                            
                                                                                                        
                                                                                                    
                                                                                                
                                                                                            
                                                                                        
                                                                                    
                                                                                
                                                                            
                                                                        
                                                                    
                                                                
                                                            
                                                        
                                                    
                                                
                                            
                                        
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                    
                
            
        
    


You are now in command of one of the most powerful fleets in history.

As Admiral, you will be required to plan and submit a Battle Plan to HQ for the forth-coming battle at Midway.  Included in this report, would be your choices for Group Unit Mix, Flag Carrier to bear you into battle, and suitable Battle group deployments for each one of your battle groups.  A good commander knows that this initial planning may hold the key to victory and will ensure that a comprehensive strategy and matching Battle group deployments are well set out into a workable plan on paper, well before any ship even begins to leave the harbor.

Having done the initial planning, you are now ready to set sail with your battle groups and put your strategic battle plan into action.  Moving your fleets out into the open ocean, you plot the moves of your Fleet Deployments onto your War Chart, watching as events unfold.  These first few moves will be crucial in determining the overall battle positions of your fleets as you head towards enemy waters.  Do you move your fleets in a broad front, or concentrate them into a narrow wedge, aimed straight for the enemy’s heart?  How would the enemy be deployed?  What is his plan?  These are questions you must ask yourself as Admiral.  Decide well, and surprise is on your side.  Decide poorly, and risk losing the initiative to a craftier enemy.

With your fleets in position, you now steam steadily towards the enemy.  The War Chart now shows the radial tracks from your scouts.  But where is the enemy?  As the gap between friend and foe narrow, a race develops to see who will be the first to spot the other.  Will luck be on your side, or will you fail to send out your scouts in a well-planned search pattern and allow enemy bombers to slip through to your vulnerable Carriers?  These are questions only you can answer as you sit and wait for the search reports to trickle in.

Suddenly, the enemy is upon you and your picket ships are hit.  As you stare out onto the flight deck from your bridge, what do you do?  Do you circle your wagons and search frantically for the enemy, throwing fighter wings into the air in the hope of slugging it out with the enemy bombers which are sure to follow, or try and scatter your ships to disappear back into the vast empty ocean to regroup?

Should you launch bombers from afar, for that long-range strike into the enemy rear, or go in close for a classic surface naval engagement with your Battleship, Cruisers and Destroyers?

Game Objectives

A win is achieved with any one of the following objectives fulfilled;

1.) Destroy all ground defenders and occupy both Midway Atoll and Wake Island with your Marines

2.) Destroy all ground defenders and occupy all three enemy home ports with your Marines

3.) Sink the enemy Flagship (Carrier or Battleship)

The game ends in a draw if no more Troop transports are still afloat from either team or when the loss of too many units on both sides make it impossible to complete the stated objectives.

Name: East vs. West (Chess)
Description:
You've all wondered about it. Some have even argued about it. Now you can play it for yourself to see which side would win.

This game was developed to help cross-understanding of the two different chess systems.

One side plays with the Western Chess pieces, the other with the Chinese Chess pieces.

Due to the differences in western and eastern chess boards, both halves of the board retain the characteristics of each side. The number of squares have been increased to accommodate the slightly larger Chinese chess board. A central row on the Chinese chess side terminates at the "river" to merge into the western chess board. Units playing at the central row interface play as per normal but with a termination at the end of the row. Bishops and Queen moving along the diagonal will side-step across the central row to maintain the same colour of squares.

Because of Eastern initial advantage checkmating with catapults in first move, West starts.

All usual rules apply.


     Western - King - 1 step in any direction
     Eastern - jiàng/shuai (General/Marshal) - 1 step in any direction (restricted to within fortress) (Korean Chess Rules)
     Western - Queen - moves diagonally and vertically/horizontally
     Eastern - shì (Scholar/Official) - 1 step in any direction (restricted to within fortress) (Korean Chess Rules)
     Western - Bishop - moves diagonally
     Eastern -  xiàng (Elephant/Minister) - moves in 2 step diagonals (blocked by a piece along its diagonal) (cannot cross river)
     Western - Knight - moves in 2/1 step "L" (blocked by a piece along the long side of the "L" when in Eastern territory)
     Eastern - ma(Horse/Cavalry) - moves in 2/1 step "L" ( blocked by a piece along the long side of "L" when in Eastern territory)
     Western - Castle - moves vertically/diagonally
     Eastern - ju (Chariot/Wagon) - moves vertically/diagonally
     Eastern - pao (Catapult/Cannon) - moves vertically/horizontally, takes enemy piece by leaping over another piece
     Western - Pawn - 1 step forward, takes enemy piece 1 step diagonally (1 or 2 step opening move)
     Eastern -zu/bing (Private/Soldier) - 1 step forward (across the river, 1 step vertically/horizontally)


Other rules;
Western Chess Unique Rules
1. Castling
2. Pawns resurrect to any previously "taken" piece upon reaching the end of board <-- no longer applies

Chinese Chess Unique Rules
1. Horses/Cavalry are blocked by pieces straddling the long leg of L <-- only within Eastern Territory
2. Elephants/Ministers are blocked by pieces straddling the diagonal
3. Privates/Soldiers can move horizontally upon crossing the river
4. General/Marshal and Shi cannot exit the fortress except when jumping out to kill opposing King in direct line of sight
5. Elephants/Ministers cannot cross the river

Some Game specific basic notes:
1. West always moves first (or East checkmates with his catapult in 1 move)
2. Korean Chess rules will be used in the case of the Eastern General and both Shi. They can now move both horizontally and diagonally along the fortress lines
3. The Eastern General retains the ability to jump in order to "take" the Western King but not vice-versa so the Western King needs to avoid "seeing" the Eastern General
4. The Western horse upon crossing the river into Eastern territory, will be subjected to the same blocking (horse-leg) rule as Eastern cavalry whilst in Eastern territory
5. The Eastern cavalry upon crossing the river into Western territory, will no longer be subjected to the blocking (horse-leg) rule whist in Western territory
6. The Western pawn no longer has the ability to upgrade to another previously "taken" piece upon reaching the end as it does so within the Eastern board

An article on the game was published in the German daily "Neues Deutschland" (transl.: "New Germany"), 22nd September 2007. http://www.nd-online.de/artikel.asp?AID=116589&IDC=27

For more info: http://www.act.com.sg/eastvswest/

Name: Tank Master
Description:
Adapted from the old Macintosh Computer game, this game pits 2 or more players in a battle to see who can programme the most efficient tank. The tank with the most efficient yet adaptable programming and subroutines will dominate the battlefield and vanquish the other tanks.

Storyline
You are a battlefield commander of an evolutionary new tank in the battlefield of the future. Wars of today are fought by remote war machines. Pitted against you is your enemy, fielding their latest war machines. This will be a fight to the finish, the struggle for supremacy.

With your superior skills as a commander, you are to programme your tank and set it loose. Win or lose will depend on your intimate knowledge of your own tank's inherent abilities as well as your uncanny reading of what your opponent's tank will do and how you perceive it would react in battle.

Win or lose, after each round, redesign, re-programme, rework your tank's subroutines and primary programming to fine-tune your tank's performance. Remember, your enemy is doing the same thing. He would have watched the previous battle and noted his tank's and your tank's performance. He too will be working to reduce deficiencies and weak points in his own programming so as to triumph over yours. Then when you're both done with your re-programming, set let them go at it again! Send out prototype after prototype until either your tanks now reign supreme in every engagement, or they all lie devastated, crushed under the steel treads of better enemy tanks.

Programming is limited to the number of standard programming tiles available in the common pile but be wary of cumbersome programming that may make your tank less than efficient as it spends a fatally long among of time processing your programming while your opponent's more efficient design finds and destroys your tank!

Gentlemen, start your engines.... and let the games begin.

Game Pieces
1 dice (to determine your tank start position on the board)
1 main "battlefield" board - (for 2P board 17steps across, + 1P add 3steps across)
2 primary programming plates
8 subroutine programming plates; 2xFight, 2xEvade, 2xFlee, 2xDamaged
1 red team light tank
1 orange team light tank
1 red team heavy tank
1 orange team heavy tank
6 "damage" pins

A) 1 step Action Tiles
i) Move Forward 1 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) Move Forward 2 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iii) Move Forward 3 (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
iv) Turn Left 1 (60 degrees) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
v) Turn Left 2 (120 degrees) (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
vi) Turn Right 1 (60 degrees) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
vii) Turn Right 2 (120 degrees) (only Light Tank) - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
viii) Reverse 1 - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ix) Complete Halt - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
x) Detect Level 3 (Logic Gate) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)

B) 2 step Action Tiles
i) Detect Level 4 (Logic Gate) (only Heavy Tank) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) Fire - (for 2P 3pcs, + 1P add 2pcs)
iii) Shield Activated - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iv) Shield Deactivated - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)

C) Decision Tiles (goto)
i) FIGHT subroutine (Logic Gate) - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
ii) FLEE subroutine - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iii) EVADE subroutine - (for 2P 5pcs, + 1P add 3pcs)
iv) return to PRIMARY - (for 2P 8pcs, + 1P add 5pcs)

notes:
1) Tank start positions are determined by a throw of the dice and placed on the corresponding number on the board
2) Action and Decision tiles are limited. Programming limited to total number of tiles on the board.
3) Tank collisions results in mutual destruction
4) Barrier/edge collisions results in halt in motion
5) Tank fire without prior detection of enemy does not hit
6) Tank fire disabled when shield is activated
7) Player to select target to hit if firing on multiple enemy
8) 2 step tile "Fire" hits on tile 2
9) 2 step tile "detect level 4" detects on both tiles 1 and 2
10) 2 step tile "shield activated" activates on tile 2
11) 2 step tile "shield deactivated" deactivates on tile 2
12) Fire range equal to detection range

Name: What's a Dame To Do?!
Description:
From the Offical Press Release:

What’s a DAME to do?!™ The socially-interactive board game - designed to spark
conversation, camaraderie and laughter - asks women to candidly predict co-players reactions to prescribed dilemmas…with extra points awarded for hilarity.

Name: Firefly Gin
Description: Card Game with a Firefly/Serenity Theme. Gin/Poker type mechanics. Seven Suites 12 cards each. Win by making combos. Specific cards also can be discarded to produce one of eight different special effects. A quick way to get that Firefly fix. The rules are available for free at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/FFG.html

Name: The Baron Munchausen Game
Description:
The Baron Munchausen Game Dice tell the story!  Your luck is read at a glance.  If you spell the word B-A-R-O-N you win  If you spell only part of the word you lose one check for every missing letter.

Game is played with 5 dice, each marked with the letters from BARON plus a blank side which is "wild" and counts for any letter.

Player wins\collects chips by throwing specific combinations.

Name: Sock it To Me!  The "IN" Game for Swingers
Description: Players take turns selecting plastic socks and if one contains the "it" disc, they must draw and "antic" card and do what that card says (e.g. "Act like a flower child") and keeps the card.  If a "Sock it to me" card is drawn, the player must perform any antic the dealer wishes them to perform.  Player with least amount of antic cards at end of the game wins.

Name: Whip
Description:
Winner is determined by whoever has all the cards at the end of the game.  After cards are dealt equally to all players, they take turns laying one down.  If someone notices two matching cards they yell Whip and takes both cards.

Cards contain very clever "whip" pictures and phrases.  There are 9 sets of 4 cards each.

Only text on box is number 503.  No publisher\manufacturer information on box or on instruction sheet.

This game is identical to the game of Snap

Name: Uncle Wiggily's New Airplane Game
Description:
From inside box cover:

The Story: That old rabbit gentleman, Uncle Wiggily, after many games and adventures, bought a farm and grew some carrots.  He used to take his carrots to market in a wheelbarrow, but one day, over the radio, he heard that airships where much faster than wheelbarrows, so he bought himself something with which he could fly in the clouds.

So here we have a playing board to represent the country over which Uncle Wiggily flew from his carrot farm to the market where he sold his yellow vegetables.  But the rabbit had so many adventures in his new airship as he did when hopping through the woods to cure his rheumatism at Dr. Possom's office.  There were storms, waterspouts and he fell into tail spins and once had to jump in a parachute.

The moves are made by drawing cards.  There are 105 white cards, each one telling you how many miles to hop Uncle Wiggily through the air.  There are 35 red cards, which may move Uncle Wiggily ahead or perhaps delay hime for a turn or two, all according to luck.

The air path, from Uncle Wiggily's farm to the market is marked by sign boards each containing a letter instead of a number.  And when these letters are separated into words, beginning at the farm, they spell out a funny little verse.  See if you can write it down after the game.

Name: Kruzifizz
Description: A tactical dice game. Try to reach the opposite side of the board with your pieces. Each player controls his own pieces AND the 3rd party on the board - neutral pieces, moved by both players.

Name: Four Horsemen: The New Game
Description:
Each player possesses a horse farm with four blocks used for horses stamped with the individual name of the horses printed on them.  Players move around the board to manage their horse farms.

The winner is the one with the most money at the end of the game.

This game was manufactured in Jamestown, ND.

Name: War Bingo
Description:
This colorful game of the latest American war machines will prove of interest to young and old alike.

There are ten types of pictures.  Each player selects 15 at random and places them face down on bingo card.  Then turns them face up and by discarding and getting new pictures, tries to create various picture combinations.  Highest points awarded for 5 American Flags in a row.  Winner is player with highest score.

Name: Down and Out
Description: Players take turns dropping marbles down the tower, one at a time.  Player with the highest score wins.

Name: No-Joke
Description:
"America's Smartest New Game"

NO-JOKE is a truly different game.  Pieces include 35 playing pieces (70 for double pack).  Pieces are wooden tongue depressors painted black with a row of 3 different shapes on each end.  The 5 shapes are hearts, spades, clubs, diamonds and stars.

The object of the game is for players put down the pieces next to each other and to line up as many shapes in a row as possible.

There are 3 versions you can play - straight No-Joke, Progressive Group No-Joke and Solitaire.

Name: Mü and Lots More
Description:
While the game Mü and much of the card art will be familiar to players of MÃ¼ & More, this release of "the best trick-taking games" has a different lineup of games (some revised) and their components, plus more cards.

This edition includes these previously-released games:

    MÃ¼
    Nyet!, revised
    Was sticht?
    Meinz

Name: Dabbawalla
Description:
Every day, amid the hustle and bustle on the busy streets of Mumbai, a remarkable feat of logistics occurs.  Hundreds of thousands of Tiffin boxes are delivered from individual houses, to the city and then onto the working people in the businesses and offices of Mumbai. What is in these Tiffin Boxes? Why, their lunch of course!
You take the role of the owner of a Dabbawalla team; your goal is to make more money than the other teams, by ensuring that you deliver the Tiffin Boxes that the businesses want, as quickly and as effectively as possible. To do this you will need to train your team in three disciplines, Speed, to help you move faster, Service, so that you get lots of Tips as you deliver, and finally Recruitment, to help grow your team.

The winner will be the player that makes the best use of their Dabbawallas, both in terms of delivering the most Tiffin Boxes, but also by recruiting the right amount of Dabbawallas and using them in chains to move Tiffin as far and as fast as possible.
   
Have you got what it takes to be the best of the best? Well, let’s play Dabbawalla and find out!

Name: Aristocats
Description: A game created and sold as merchandise of the Walt Disney movie Aristocats. A game mostly for kids.

Name: Mish Mosh: The Jewish Word Game
Description:
Mish Mosh - The Jewish Word Game includes rules in both Yiddish and English for the titular game Mish Mosh, which has striking similarities to Scrabble.  There are also "student rules" that include three variants requiring increasing education:


     Identifying the Alphabet - Simply select a letter from your tray, say what it is, then place it on the matching letter on the board.  Congratulations!  You just earned 5 points.
     "Mish Moshing" the Language - Build sentences out of English words written somewhat phonetically with Hebrew letters.
     Historical Mish Mosh - This variation can be played by any number of players.  One player thinks of a "a famous Jewish Historical person", then spells his or her name with the tiles.  (e.g. ABRAHAM)  The next person must think of another whose name starts with the final letter of the previous one.  (e.g. MOSHEH).  This is an elimination game like HORSE:  Each time you fail, you "earn" a letter of MISH MOSH.  Once you have spelled the whole name, you are out.


Each tile has both the traditional print letter and its handwritten equivalent.  There are no tiles for "final" forms of letters.

Name: Hancock's Half Hour
Description: This Chad Valley Board game from the early 1960's is based on Tony Hancock and his classic Hancock's Half Hour British television program. Hancock's Half Hour was a ground-breaking and influential BBC radio comedy series of the 1950s, starring Tony Hancock, with Sid James, Hattie Jacques, Bill Kerr and Kenneth Williams. From 1956 it also became a television comedy series. This is basically a track move game.

Name: Horse Show
Description:
"Buying, Selling and Trading Horses - From the Horse People"

This game is designed and published by Paul Burnham, American Saddlebred Training Stables, Jonesboro, GA.

This game provides players with an understanding of what horses and their breeders go through and deal with in the showing of horses - a sense of realism is hoped in case you want to know what it's really like owning a horse.

To win, a player must have a complete show string (one 5-gaited, one 3-gaited, one road horse, one fine harness, one pleasure horse and one risk horse) and a total of 500 points.

Name: JokerFace
Description: JokerFace is a card game where players try to run out of cards they are holding.  Players connect cards from their hand to those played face-up on the table.  Cards are connected by matching symbols (Hearts, Diamonds, Spades and Clubs).  Some cards have Jokers on them, which are wild.  There are also 8 Face cards (King, Queen, Jack, and Ace) that give players special abilities during the game.  If players can place a card that connects to two cards simultaneously, they may play an additional card the same turn.  Players start their turns by drawing a card, so playing more than one each turn is vital.  Each card also has text on it (Blue or Red), that create special circumstances (Rotating cards 90 degrees, Flipping them 180 degrees, and Moving them to another location on the "board").  Some cards played allow you to automatically play additional cards, and some force you to draw more.

Name: Roks
Description:
Roks are domino-like pieces with Ace - King characters on each end.  There are 36 pieces in the complete set.

There are eight games you can play with Roks:

Rokem - similar to normal dominos
Roker - variation to Rokem
Roket - Played with only 28 pieces and players bid on hands, using trump suits.
Orbit - 6 player bidding game played in teams,
Roks - 4 player game.  Bid for a contracted number of tricks
Straights - 2 player game.  Try to create 4 or more ROKS in a row with low end alike and high end descending.
Roksol - Solitaire game
Hilorok - similar to stud poker

Name: Then There Were None...
Description:
From the publisher's website: A lot of creatures are disappearing because they are being over-hunted and their natural habitats destroyed. Can we do the needed research to initiate Laws and Conservation Methods to save as many endangered species as we can?

Lots of decision making for each player. The basic game plays quickly, with advanced rules for older players!

Includes: 20 endangered creature cards, 50 research, protection, hunting and habitat tokens, project marker, educational booklet with species information, rules.

Ages 9 and up

Name: Domination: Sabot & Laser
Description:
Domination: Sabot & Laser is the miniature rules for simulating the battles between the Kalotian Empire and the First and Second Allied Armies of Earth during the Kalotian invasion of Earth in the early 1990's.  The game is compatible with Domination, the sister RPG from Starchilde.

The game uses 6mm scale miniatures to represent Human and Kalotian forces.  The miniatures for Human forces could be obtained from vendors such as GHQ. The game was slated to have custom Kalotian 6mm miniatures, but ultimately none were ever made. However there are a number of grav style tank 6mm models that could be used in their stead such as C-in-Cs Renegade Legion miniatures.

Name: Speculation
Description:
Speculation is the simple fast moving stock market game that embraces the quick fluctuations in price typical of the market of speculative securities.

The object of the game is for each player to increase his beginning net worth of $12,000 by "buying low" and "selling high" as prices of individual securities rise and fall on the Market Board.

The wooden market board is used to track the price of each stock (eight areas are Advertising, Aircraft, Automobile, Cosmetics, Electronics, Mining, Paper & Petroleum).  Users keep track of game play on their Security Record sheets.

Winner is determined by calculating each individual's net worth consisting of both cash and the current market value of the securities they hold.

Name: Super Fun
Description: Objective is to match card combinations to the game board squares.  Remove golf tees from the game bard by creating number combinations with the cards - using addition, subtraction and multiplication.  Players are awarded points based on the color of their tees.  Winner has highest amount of points.

Name: Game of Telegrams
Description:
Players complete to be the first to create 10 word telegrams using cards with words provided.

Game No. 1 is played creating any 10 word humorous or serious telegram, as the player chooses.  Game No. 2 is played re-creating telegram messages printed on each form.

Name: Oly-opoly
Description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

A customized Monopoly set focused on Olympia, Washington, USA.

Name: Flying Aces
Description:
This is a game of aerial battles.

Each player gets 3 planes and using dice  they move them from their take-off (starting) points onto the battle map.  The planes follow the paths in circular movement resembling a "dog fight" in the air, for position. 
 Using the roll of the dice the player may move 1, 2 or all 3 of his planes.  Doubles earns an extra roll of the dice, but only twice in a row.  If he jumps over an enemy plane by a roll of the dice it is considered shot down.

When only one player's planes are left on the board the game is over and the owner is declared the winner.

Name: Monopoly: Littlest Pet Shop
Description: It's Monopoly with the "Littlest Pet Shop" children's toy theme. Same as original Monopoly, with all of the board spaces, cards, tokens, etc. Includes 4 or 6 actual "Littlest Pet Shop" toys, depending on version.

Name: Pathfinder
Description: This is a game targeted to assist company executives, marketing, sales, and product managers; you creatively brainstorm through a set of played cards that guide you in creating products and determining the way you will distribute them, advertise them, and how you will manage risks.

Name: Iron Bottom Sound II
Description:
Iron Bottom Sound 2 is a tactical simulation of night naval surface combat in WW2.
Iron Bottom Sound 2 captures the flavor of bloody night surface battles fought off Guadalcanal.
A past property has been succeeded because it focuses it on the combat at nighttime though the system was greatly changed from the Ironbottom Sound.  
The only fault of this game should be very large the size of the map board, and widely take up the place where it plays. 
Moreover, it is necessary to confirm it before it plays because the correction is necessary for the table relation though somewhat.


    Game system
        Basic System is Fleet Admiral.
        But Gunnery system is Royal Navy. 
        Dice is BOTH 6 and 10 sided dice are required.
        Torpedo combat is the basis of firing at the mega-hexs of the map.
        Turn Scale:3 minutes,Hex Scale:600 yards
    
    Ship Data
        All the ship data was reviewed. 
        Especially, the armor of all ships has thinned as for the Sea of Japan army. 
        The appearance country is United States,Japan,British,German,Commonwealth,Italian.
    
    Scenario
        10 Scenario
            Battle of Cape Esperance
            Battle of Kula Gulf
            The Battle of Tassafaronga
            Second Battle of Guadalcanal
            The Battle of Kolambangara
            Duisburg Convoy
            First Battle of Guadalcanal
            Channel Action
            The Battle of Empress Augusta Bay
            The Battle of Savo Island
        
    
    Component
        2 22"x34"map
        2 island map
        210 die-cut counter
        18 pages of Roser Sheets
        5 Player aid Cards
        1 Rule Booklet

Name: Roulette Baseball
Description: Roulette Baseball, © Wm. Bartholomae produced in 1929 was a very simple spin the spinner to get the results game. There were more than 30 results that were possible when the spinner stopped. No skill involved, simply spin the spinner and see what happens to your team.

Name: The Greatest Adventure: Stories from the Bible – The Nativity
Description:
The Nativity

Journey through the Holy Land when Jesus was born.

This fun and easy game is intended to help understand the stories, events, and people in the Bible with questions and answers.

Each player in turn reads a question card.  The player turns over the question card to see if the question was answered correctly.  If correct, the player moves forward on the game path the same number of spaces indicated on the card.

No spinners or dice are used.

Name: Blitz: The Air Raid Game
Description:
Blitz is played on a board with 60 squares.  Each squares represents a property or building such as railway stations, shops, etc.  Each property has a value as marked.

The four center squares in the board are not marked and are used to start the game. The game is played with 60 bombs (red on one end and black on the other).  To start the game 4 bombs (2 red end up and 2 black end up) are placed in the center four squares diagonally opposite each other.  The attacker (using the red end) places a red bomb on any square where it will bracket a black bomb between it and a red bomb already on the map.  When he does this he flips the black bomb over to red.  The defender (using black) does the same with his black bomb, being sure to bracket a red bomb with his black.   If a player is unable to find a legal place he loses his turn.

Play continues alternately until all 60 squares are filled.    At that point the bombs are removed and the points on the squares underneath are totaled up.  The high points wins.

Name: Qbiczu
Description:
Taken from Qbic toys homepage:

Played by 2 players or 2 teams, each taking a turn to fill one of 27 potential spaces in a 3x3x3 cube.

The placeholders are represented by balls, normally 14 black and 13 orange.

The objective is to place 3 balls of the same colour in a row or column scoring a point for each unique vertical, horizontal or diagonal row (including internally through the cube)

QbicZu is won by the player achieving the MOST “3 in a row” and not simply the first “3 in a row” .

Name: Hold the Fort
Description:
From the rules: There are 50 pieces or "men" constituting the Attacking Force use and Three "Officers" constituting the Garrison of the Fort.

Place the 50 pieces on the black spots outside the fort, the defender places the 3 officers on any of the dots on the front rampart of the fort.

The object of the attacking force is by solidly pressing forward to fill the 13 spaces of the fort.

The object of the garrison is to destroy the advancing force by jumping over and removing pieces so that the attacker cannot win the game.

Each player moves alternately.  The defender can move on black and red lines in any direction.  The defender can also jump over and remove any enemy on an adjacent spot if a vacant spot exists beyond.  The attacker cannot jump and cannot move backward on the red lines.

Name: Spot-a-Plane
Description:
The board represents a military strategy map of enemy territory with numerous objective spots from Take Off to Mission Accomplished.

The players advance through the map by identifying silhouettes of friendly and enemy planes.  Success allows the player to move forward the number of spaces listed on the card.  Failure requires the player to back up as noted on the card.  Other spaces on the map include the Army Flash and Danger Flash spots.  These force the player to draw a card and follow the instructions noted.

First person to the Mission Accomplished space wins the game.

Name: Flotilla
Description:
From the rules:  A game of Naval Manoeuvres for two players.  Each player manoeuvres his fleet with the object of occupying naval bases of his opponent to the value of 100 points.  Whilst planning attack, defence, must not be neglected, and much strategy is required for manoeuvring to the best advantage.

Differences in strength and speed of the various units of the fleet and in the configuration of the coasts marked on the charts are such that innumerable situations arise, and the game is full of variety.

Each player has 1 battleship, 1 submarine, 3 cruisers, and 5 destroyers and they are PINNED (yep pinned) onto the board to show their location.  Bases are captured by ships entering them and they are marked by pins to show ownership.   Each ship has a movement value (for example destroyers rate a 3) and in a turn a player cannot move more than 10 points.  To resolve battles the teetotum is used.

It has 6 Bs (Battleship) 4 Cs (Cruiser) and 2 Ds (Destroyer).  Its is spun and if the letter matches the attacking ships its a hit (submarines always use the letter of the ship they are attacking so they have an equal chance against any ship).

Very interesting game and you get to push pins into a board.

Name: Bomber Attack
Description: A very simple game where players move down a path based on a spin of the spinner.  Actions can result based on where the space landed on by each player.

Name: Rules for World War I Naval
Description:
Naval wargames rules covering the period 1914-1928. Designed to be played with 1:3000 models on a tabletop or 1:1200 models in a hall. Originally published in 1973. This entry based on the 1975 second edition. 
The rules have an introduction to the period followed by rule concepts and ship statistic calculation rules. Then firing guns and torpedoes, hitting mines, clearing mines fuel, submarines, ramming and weather are covered. The final section of the rulebook covers statistics for ships of the period plus where to buy models and get reference material: a task much easier now with the advent of the internet.
The ground scale used is 1:6 and time scale is 1 minute per turn. 
Some preparation is required before play can commence as turning circles must be made and ship statistics calculated for the ships in action.

Name: Schotts Sammelsurium
Description:
Based on the same Book about useless bits of knowledge by Ben Schott.

Simple trivia game: One person reads the question (usually something you don't know) and the 3 possible answers. Everyone uses his marker to guess the correct answer. Right guesses means you move your pawn forward.

More guessing than knowing.
